Also prepping for tech interviews

Also, I am still not sure how to self-study ME at home. If you know the great methods or tools, please let me know!

articles.author: alok-38
articles.description:
Have you ever needed to clean up a project directory but didn‚Äôt want to lose your hidden files or the all-important README.md?


Let‚Äôs talk about a simple, safe, and powerful command-line trick to do just that ‚Äî using find.
Say you‚Äôve built and compiled several binaries, created temporary files, or generated test outputs. You want to wipe everything except:
Hidden files (e.g., .git, .env, .gitignore)
README.md
But using something like rm * will delete almost everything ‚Äî and it won‚Äôt touch hidden files, which can be misleading. You need a smarter, safer approach.
find . -maxdepth 1 ! -name '.*' ! -name 'README.md' ! -name '.' -exec rm -rf {} +


find . -maxdepth 1: Only search in the current directory (not recursively).
! -name '.*': Don‚Äôt touch hidden files/directories.
! -name 'README.md': Keep your documentation safe.
! -name '.': Prevent deleting the current directory.
-exec rm -rf {} +: Delete everything else ‚Äî files and folders.
Before:
$ ls -al
calculator  calculator.c  func  func.c  hello  hello.c  ...
.git  .gitignore  README.md


After:
$ find . -maxdepth 1 ! -name '.*' ! -name 'README.md' ! -name '.' -exec rm -rf {} +
$ ls -al
.git  .gitignore  README.md


Before running rm -rf, test the output with:
find . -maxdepth 1 ! -name '.*' ! -name 'README.md' ! -name '.' -exec echo {} +


This prints the files that would be deleted.
Finally run:
find . -maxdepth 1 ! -name '.*' ! -name 'README.md' ! -name '.' -exec rm -rf {} +
articles.title: Pro Bash Tip: Preserve Hidden Files and README.md While Deleting Everything Else

articles.author: MediaGeneous
articles.description:
How to Build a Simple Chatbot with Python
Chatbots have become an essential tool for businesses, customer support, and even personal projects. Whether you're looking to automate responses, engage users, or just experiment with natural language processing (NLP), building a chatbot in Python is a great way to start.
In this guide, we'll walk through creating a simple chatbot using Python. We'll cover the basics of NLP, how to process user input, and generate responses. By the end, you'll have a functional chatbot that you can expand upon.
P.S. If you're looking to grow your YouTube channel, try MediaGeneous for expert strategies and growth hacks.
Prerequisites
Before we begin, ensure you have the following installed:
Python 3.6+
pip (Python package manager)
Basic knowledge of Python programm‚Ä¶
articles.title: How to Build a Simple Chatbot with Python

articles.author: hari A.G
articles.description:
JavaScript is the scripting language that brings interactivity to your websites. One of its most powerful features is the ability to manipulate the DOM (Document Object Model)‚Äîessentially the structure of your HTML‚Äîusing variables.
In this blog, we'll break down:
‚Ä¢What variables are in JavaScript
‚Ä¢How they interact with HTML through the DOM
‚Ä¢Examples of how to use them effectively
üß† What Are JavaScript Variables?
Variables in JavaScript are used to store data that you can use later in your code. Think of them as labeled containers for values like numbers, strings, or even entire HTML elements.
Declaring Variables
üåø Introduction to the DOM
The DOM (Document Object Model) is a tree-like structure created by the browser from your HTML. It lets JavaScript read and manipulate elements on the page.
Here‚Äôs a simple HTML example:
Welcome!
In this example, JavaScript can access and change the 
 element using the DOM.


üõ†Ô∏è Using Variables to Change the DOM
Let‚Äôs write the script.js:
function changeTitle() {
‚Ä¢newTitle is a variable storing the new message.
‚Ä¢document.getElementById("title") accesses the 
 element by its ID.


‚Ä¢innerText = newTitle updates the content of the 
.


üîÑ Dynamically Changing Styles
You can also use variables to change styles:
function changeColor() {
 text color to blue when the function is called.


üöÄ Conclusion
Next Step: Try building a simple form or interactive quiz using what you‚Äôve learned. It‚Äôs a great way to solidify your understanding!
articles.title: DAY‚úåÔ∏èOF JAVASCRIPT .JavaScript Variables and the DOM in HTML: A Beginnerüìö

articles.title: Day 3: Session 2: JavaScript DOM Manipulation + Template Literals

articles.author: Claire Mahoney
articles.description:
Personally I hate FAQs. I think they are a lazy way of presenting content. They are a black hole of information, with zero information scent and no context. 
So it was really disappointing to find out that AI likes (even prefers) content in that format. A question with an answer. I get that LLMs like tight info relationships, but understanding those relationships in multiple contexts is AI's job. Providing the best smelling info scent is the mission. So why do I need to dumb down my content for AI?
There's this thing now called AEO and it's like SEO but for AI models. AI is more likely to surface the content that you write, if it's in a format AI likes to digest. FAQs are like cheese on toast apparently. Delicious and quick to make.
Forgive me if I have higher expectations of our new robot overlords. The content I make is structured, clear, well-expressed, mildly spiced, and made for every palate, human palates especially. 
If we feed AI the same thing all the time, it's going to regurgitate the same back on us. And is never going to "learn" to get its nutrition from variety of foods. So if you see the terms "AEO" or "AIEO" don't believe the hype. Feed your AI a balanced diet, and not bread all the time.
articles.title: I hate FAQs and they might make AI dumb

articles.author: Chig Beef
articles.description:
One of the most important things I was forced to create in school was minesweeper. This is because it brings up recursion, which every programmer seems to struggle with. Heck, in university, there are many students that still don't grasp it, halfway through the degree. So when people ask how they can learn recursion, my favorite task is minesweeper. And, of course, you get a cool game out of it!
So, here's the challenge, can we make it in one day? Don't start the timer yet, we must design first, list out what we have to do. That's the good part of games like these, they are well-defined, and can be described in a page. I'll describe the game in long form, from the perspective of interactions from the user. I'll then list out notes on these features. In concept, if our application adheres t‚Ä¶
articles.title: Make In A Day: Minesweeper

articles.author: Leonardo Marciano
articles.description:
Catch bugs early and keep your users happy.
Encore deploys your backend in minutes, but once it‚Äôs live you need visibility into what happens after users start clicking. In this post we‚Äôll wire Encore with Sentry so that:
Any unhandled exception in an API route or background job is captured with a full stack trace, request metadata, and deployment tag.
Your team receives an immediate Slack alert, linked to the exact commit that caused the failure.
Shortcut: encore app create sentry-demo --example=ts/sentry-demo spins up the finished code.
Without observability you‚Äôre blind to:
Silent failures ‚Äì background workers stuck in retry loops.
Hot‚Äëpath regressions ‚Äì a typo that breaks payment processing.
Unknown unknowns ‚Äì edge‚Äëcase inputs you never tested.
Continuous monitoring closes the feedback ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Integrating Sentry Error Monitoring with Encore.ts
